Traveler\"s diarrhea_1:
Patient Description 1:
A 28-year-old male patient, with a history of frequent international travel, presented with a chief complaint of passage of loose, watery stools (4-5 times a day) along with an urgent need to defecate and abdominal cramps. He reported experiencing nausea, without vomiting, and a low-grade fever. The patient described his abdominal pain as moderate (4/10) and reported no signs of dehydration. His medical history is unremarkable, and he is not currently taking any medications. The onset of symptoms coincided with his recent travel to a region known for gastroenteritis outbreaks.
Traveler\"s diarrhea_2:
Patient Description 2:
A 35-year-old female patient, who returned from a trip to a tropical country, reported a 3-day history of traveler's diarrhea. She described frequent, loose, watery stools (more than 3 times a day) and an urgent need to defecate, accompanied by abdominal cramps. The patient experienced nausea and several episodes of vomiting, contributing to mild dehydration. She also noted the presence of a fever (101°F) and reported moderate abdominal pain (6/10) and rectal pain (5/10). The patient has no significant medical history and is not taking any regular medications.
Traveler\"s diarrhea_3:
Patient Description 3:
A 40-year-old male patient, recently returned from a backpacking trip in a developing country, presented with traveler's diarrhea symptoms. He reported passing loose, watery stools 5-6 times a day and described an urgent need to defecate, along with severe abdominal cramps. The patient experienced persistent vomiting, high fever (103°F), and reported severe pain in the abdomen (8/10) and rectum (7/10). These symptoms had led to moderate to severe dehydration, as evidenced by dry mouth, reduced urine output, and increased drowsiness. The patient has no significant underlying medical conditions and is not on any regular medications.
